captions.text:
Airplanes stay in the air because of one simple
fact: there is no net force on them. And with

no net force, an object at rest stays at rest,
and an object in motion stays that way – even

if it’s in midair 10 km above the earth’s
surface.

Now of course it’s not like there aren’t
forces acting on the airplane; gravity pulls

down on the plane itself plus all of the people
and baggage inside, and every single air molecule

that is shot through the engine or collides
with the fuselage or wings pushes on the plane

as well. But if all of these forces are balanced
– in particular, if the air molecules push

the plane UP enough to counteract gravity
– then the plane stays up.

Getting air molecules to push the plane up
is the crucial part of flying, and planes

do this by making sure the undersides of the
wings crash into more air molecules more violently

than the upper sides of the wings. When a
plane is parked on the ground, air molecules

bounce off of the top and bottom of the wings
in roughly equal amounts, or with “equal
pressure.” No lift.

But in motion, the curved shape of the wings
and their slightly inclined angle means that

the bottoms smash into more air molecules
than before (and smash harder into those molecules),

so the pressure on the bottom of the wing
goes up.

In addition, fewer air molecules now strike
the top of the wing and those that do strike

it less forcefully, partly because it’s
being “shielded” by its own forward motion

(the way running into the rain keeps your
back drier) and partly because a curving stream

of air has lower pressure on the inside of
the curve since the molecules get thrown centripetally

to the outside. But whatever the reasons,
the pressure on the top of the wing goes down.

So, low pressure on the top plus high pressure
on the bottom, and the plane has lift. And

if the pressure/force imbalance is big enough,
it can lift the plane up into the air against
gravity!

Now, all this crashing into air molecules
to lift the plane also pushes to slow the

plane down – which it would, if not for
engines. Engines also push air (in this case,

backwards), either via a propellor, or a jet,
or a jet driving a propellor. For various

reasons, it turns out that you want to have
a really big propellor driven by a really
small jet for the most efficient engine.

But even in inefficient engines, the spinning
fan blades get their horizontal lift, which

we call “thrust,” by moving quickly through
air with a curved shape and a slightly inclined
angle – they’re essentially mini-wings.

And so an airplane is essentially a meta-wing:
it flies by moving mini-wings fast enough

to push air molecules backwards, which moves
the plane forward fast enough that its big
wings push air molecules down.
Whoa. Wingception.

comments.text:
Ooooh! Soo close! Firstly, the AoA (angle of attack) isn't so important, 
and it is more the aerodynamic shape of the aerofoil. Secondly, where you 
marked the camber, that's called the 'chord line', the camber is the 
vertical measurement of the aerofoil. Thirdly, gravity doesn't pull down on 
it, WEIGHT pulls down on it... If gravity was pulling down on it, it'd be 
tumbling out of the sky...

Just to let you know, I'm a pilot in the RAF, and have been for 12 years... 
It's been too long...﻿

comments.author: usef yasin

comments.text:
nice easy explaining video.
I only missed 1 thing, and that is the effect of AoA on the airflow on both 
sides of the wing. You explained it as airparticles bumping into the wing, 
which is true to an extent, but because of the AoA the speed of the airflow 
on the long side of the wing is increased thus creating an underpressure 
(and the resulting force is lift)
So in one sentence; the angle of attack influences the speed and pressure 
of the airflow over the wing relative to the speed and pressure under the 
wing.
However, there is a limit to how far you can do this (maximum angle of 
attack)
Above AoAmax the airflow over the top gets distorted and "leaves" the wing 
in a turbulent flow instead of streaming to near the back of the wing, thus 
losing most of the lift and that is what we call a stall. It is not as if 
there are alot of airparticles hitting the top of the wing all of a sudden, 
but the loss the lowpressure airflow over the wing﻿

comments.author: PLadouce

comments.text:
In flight school we were taught that Bernoulli's Theorem is the primary 
cause of lift, with Newtonian lift being a less-important but still 
relevant factor. The Airbus in the model wouldn't use a standard aerofoil 
like the one shown in the video, like most passenger jets it would use a 
"supercritical wing", which we were told is better for speeds closer to the 
speed of sound. However we weren't taught how these supercritical wings 
generate lift (though I'm sure it's quite different to a standard 
aerofoil).﻿

comments.author: Eric Johansson

comments.text:
i dont agree. the first part u were explaining the wing as if it were a 
piece of plywood....strap an engine to a piece of plywood, increase its 
angle of attack and that plywood will fly.

while this is true, it is extremely inefficient and isn't actually wat's 
going on.

u then proceeded to talk about pressure, which at least is sort of correct.

there are 2 theories on how airplanes fly. (yes they're still just 
theories, not absolute certainties yet)

the first theory is bernoulli's principle. the upper wing accelerates air 
faster than the bottom wing, faster velocity=lower pressure, pressure 
difference causes "lift"

the second theory, which i think is more true, is newton's third law. for 
ever action there is an equal opposite reaction.

air molecules come into contact with top surface of wing, adheres to the 
surface, follows the camber (curve) of the wing and is accelerated 
downwards. the downward acceleration imposes a force equal and opposite, 
thus pushing the wing up which we call lift.

this theory can be tested by a multitude of ways

sit in a shopping cart with bricks. throw bricks in one direction and u 
(and the shopping cart) will begin to move in the opposite direction

also

grab a spoon, turn on ur tap. holding the spoon at this rear tip vertically 
so that it's parallel with the water flow. now slowly bring in the back 
side of the spoon (convex side) so that it enters the water stream. most 
ppl will think that the water stream will "push" the spoon away, but when 
in actuality the spoon will be "sucked" into the stream, similar to the way 
airplane wing's work﻿

comments.author: Soufiane Kharroubi

comments.text:
+Soufiane Kharroubi   Well...  You're somewhat, sorta'  right.  You can't 
"suck" in air - that is only a oversimplified explanation, though by the 
common usage of 'suck' it actually is correct.   ...From the pedantic 
society:When you lower the pressure in one region, the higher pressure in 
surrounding regions pushes air into the lower pressure region.   You must 
have a pressure difference.  A vacuum cleaner uses atmospheric pressure to 
push air and dirt into the vacuum hose by virtue of the greatly reduced 
pressure inside the machine. ...It turns out, much to the confusion of 
many, that this part of Bernoulli''s Equation is nothing more than Newton's 
laws.... it takes a force to accelerate a mass and that applys to fluids as 
well.  The force is pressure and the mass is a mass of air just like any 
other mass....When there is more presure below the wing and less above, 
this is a net force upward.  There is an increase in pressure below an 
airfoil, but it is a smaller contribution, as you say, to the difference 
than the reduced pressure above it.  The fact that the lowered pressure 
above the wing is a major contributor to lift is one of the nonintuitive 
aspects of lift that confounds many amateur.  ...The other is this long 
propagated myth that faster air *creates* reduced pressure and it has 
become known as "Bernoulli's Principle".  Some like to say that 
"Bernoulli's Principle makes lift" without explaining what that means, what 
their understanding of the "principle" actually is, or how it comes comes 
to result in lift....Then as a flame shield for me......This pressure 
difference (caused by several things going on around the wing) also causes 
a downard acceleration of air behind the wing, called downwash, which is 
the result of the necessary "equal and opposite" reaction force on the 
air.  I point to four major things happening around the wing and the 
downwash as being the major phenomena of lift.-- Cheers, 
ScienceAdviserStaveSecond vice charman of the N.E. Illinois subchalper if 
the US partner of International Pedantic Society and Vice President of the 
Education and Conference committee. (;-D)

comments.author: Accidental Hipster

comments.text:
Really? Bernoulli Effect? 
It may contribute in a very small amount, but if that was the case, 
aircraft would not stall. 
Lets make a kitchen experiment. Turn on the tap then take a spoon hold it 
from the handle with two fingers (as if it is hanging). Now place it on the 
water stream with the back in first. You will see the spoon moving in to 
the stream of water!!!
WHAT? But the stream of water certainly has higher pressure than the static 
air on the other side of the spoon!!!
The thing that makes aeroplanes fly (apart of money :) ) is the 
action-reaction. When the airstream at the top of the wing follows the 
curvature, it is pushed down. The mass of air pushed down has the opposite 
effect to the wing (pushing it up) due to the above mentioned phenomenon. 
Now, why did I mention stall? Well, if that air at the top just stops 
following the wing's top curve, then the wing is in stall state. That means 
that it produces negative lift (pushing down) rather than the positive lift 
that neutralises gravity. 
When does the airflow not follow the curvature of the wing? well, long 
story short, when the wing exceeds a specific angle-of-attack then it goes 
in to stall state. That can happen in high speeds (crazy right?)﻿
comments.author: Alex Rantos

comments.text:
+Alex Rantos   No.  The static pressure in the stream of water must be 
precisely the same as the ambient air around it.  In order for the water to 
have the curved path around the convex shape of the spoon, there must be a 
force making it curve in that radial acceleration.  This is just like the 
radial acceleratin of an orbiting satellite that is caused by the force of 
gravity that accelerates the satellite radially inward, only changing its 
direction and not (tangential) speed....A higher pressure on the outside of 
the curve compared to the inside of the curved path.  In essence, radial 
acceleration....And are you sure that viscocity and wetting have nothing to 
do with the water-spoon demo?  In other words, what about the boundary 
layer of the water...And just what is that "above mentioned phenomenon" ??  
What law of standard physics it is?...Then, if it is simply because the 
"airstream at the top of the wing follows the curvature, it is pushed 
down", then why, pray-tell, does such a large volume of air, from far above 
the wing, get shoved down so rapidly (abt 10 m/s for a real heavy) in the 
following video  ...?See the GREEN video on one of these sites.  It is a 
test of a model of the A380 in a French aerodynamics facility....[ 
Originally from here:   http://www.gifday.com/how-wings-create-lift/  ] But 
GifDay appears down/gone  now.
Availible here, William Beaty's site: http://amasci.com/wing/airgif2.html...
